abstract.p: Gage Marketing Group is acquiring Kuester Partners, with billings estimated at $25 million, and Wilshire Group, with billings estimated at $20 million; Kevin Kuester, chief executive at Kuester, becomes consultant to Gage; Bob Rubin, chief executive at Wilshire, becomes vice president and general manager for technology channel marketing at Gage; Gage acquires 40 percent stake in Marketing Bridge, with revenue estimated at $4 million; Gage signs letter of intent to acquire 50 percent stake in Bitstream Underground, with revenue estimated at $4 million; Gary Clark, chief executive at Bitstream, becomes vice president and general manager for e-business at Gage (Advertising column) (S)

block.p: The Gage Marketing Group in Irvine, Calif., and Minneapolis has made three acquisitions and signed a letter of intent for a fourth.

Gage is acquiring 100 percent of two agencies, which will be absorbed into Gage. One is Kuester Partners in Minneapolis, with 25 employees and billings estimated at $35 million from clients like General Mills. Kevin Kuester, 52, chief executive at Kuester, becomes a consultant to Gage. The other is the Wilshire Group in Irvine, specializing in Web-based marketing for the technology industry, with 15 employees and billings estimated at $20 million from clients like Intel and Microsoft. Bob Rubin, 58, chief executive at Wilshire, becomes vice president and general manager for technology channel marketing at Gage.

Gage is acquiring 100 percent of two agencies, which will be absorbed into Gage. One is Kuester Partners in Minneapolis, with 25 employees and billings estimated at $35 million from clients like General Mills. Kevin Kuester, 52, chief executive at Kuester, becomes a consultant to Gage. The other is the Wilshire Group in Irvine, specializing in Web-based marketing for the technology industry, with 15 employees and billings estimated at $20 million from clients like Intel and Microsoft. Bob Rubin, 58, chief executive at Wilshire, becomes vice president and general manager for technology channel marketing at Gage.

Gage acquired a 40 percent stake in Marketing Bridge in Edina, Minn., a Web development and electronic-commerce engineering agency, with 15 employees and revenue estimated at $4 million from clients like General Electric and Kraft Foods. Frantz Corneille, 55, president and chief executive at Marketing Bridge, continues in that role.

The letter of intent involves a 50 percent stake in Bitstream Underground in Minneapolis, an interactive design and programming agency with 23 employees and revenue estimated at $4 million from clients like Digital River. Gary Clark, 47, chief executive at Bitstream, becomes vice president and general manager for e-business at Gage.
